item.content:encoded: 'Gay Obama' Newsweek Mag Also Shoehorns in a Knock on Palin http://t.co/H0RfwEf5 #twisters #tcot #WAR Inside the cover of the most recent issue of Newsweek, adorned by a rainbow haloed President Obama as the “first gay president,” is an article about New Mexico governor Susana Martinez. The article is largely positive piece about Governor Martinez’s compelling life story, her successes in the first year and a half of her term as governor, and what she could contribute to the national GOP as a whole and presumptive nominee Mitt Romney specifically. item.title: As Obama OKs Weapons to Bahrain, Neurosurgeon Tortured by Regime Faces Trial for Treating Protesters
item.description: As Obama OKs Weapons to Bahrain, Neurosurgeon Tortured by Regime Faces Trial For Treating Protesters http://t.co/vEmVxOJN #union
item.content:encoded: As Obama OKs Weapons to Bahrain, Neurosurgeon Tortured by Regime Faces Trial For Treating Protesters http://t.co/vEmVxOJN #union Human rights organizations are criticizing the Obama administration’s decision to resume military sales to Bahrain despite the ruling monarchy’s ongoing repression of pro-democracy protests. The State Department has said it will allow a multi-million-dollar weapons shipment to the Bahraini government, citing "national security interests." The announcement came just days after the Bahraini government vowed "tougher action" in its crackdown on protesters. We’re joined by Dr. Nabeel Hameed, who is one of Bahrain’s only neurosurgeons and among dozens of Bahraini physicians and nurses who have been arrested and tried for treating anti-government protesters. After a three-month prison stint that he says included abuse and torture, Dr. Hameed is expected to be tried by a Bahraini court soon after he returns home. "There is this silence, this deafening silence, from the world governments [about Bahrain]," he says. "There is a situation which is really getting worse and worse. And if you don’t really stop it here, it may get really, really bad in the future. ... You don’t have to wait until the violence propagates out of control." [includes rush transcript] Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: democracynow.org

item.title: Printed books existed nearly 600 years before Gutenberg's Bible
item.description: Printed books existed nearly 600 years before Gutenberg's Bible [Secret History] http://t.co/3Y9Ndve3. #news (connex.us)
item.content:encoded: Printed books existed nearly 600 years before Gutenberg's Bible [Secret History] http://t.co/3Y9Ndve3. #news (connex.us) It is a little-known but undisputed historical fact that Johannes Gutenberg did not invent the printing press. Though the Gutenberg Bible was certainly the first mass produced printed work, it was hardly the first printed book — nor was it even the first made using movable type. Chinese and Korean inventors had been producing printed books for centuries before Gutenberg was born. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: io9.com

item.title: ongoing by Tim Bray · Browsers and Apps in 2012
item.description: Enough with both the “Apps are dead” and ”Web is dead” red herrings (with linkography): http://t.co/cHnmKv0Z
item.content:encoded: Enough with both the “Apps are dead” and ”Web is dead” red herrings (with linkography): http://t.co/cHnmKv0Z It’s like this: The browser’s doomed, because apps are the future. Wait! Apps are doomed because HTML5 is the future. I see something almost every day saying one or the other. Only it’s mostly wrong. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: tbray.org

item.title: When superyacht chic meets hybrid technology - CNN.com

item.content:encoded: When superyacht chic meets hybrid technology - CNN http://t.co/e1sm0dU1 How does the wealthy boating enthusiast reconcile a passion for gas-guzzling superyachts with concern for the natural ocean environment? Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: cnn.com
